Name: Naturally Nirvana
Review: ong>Not purists, that's for certain. This is a coffee for adventurers interested in sampling an unusual blend that includes beans from a rare species of coffee. Some who taste it may decide that Liberica ought to stay rare, but others may find interest in its bitter nut character, softened here by pairing with a good Mexico natural.

Name: Guatemalan Organic Light Roast

Name: Organic Ethiopian
Review: ong>Those who seek a bright, citrusy cup with impeccable environmental and social credentials.

Name: Organic Sumatra
Review: ong>Basic Sumatra character, with respectable social and environmental credentials.

Name: Colombia Medium Roast
Review: ong>A straightforward coffee for those who prefer body and richness to brightness and complexity. Given the volume and anonymity of coffee needed to fill the bins of this proprietary brand, however, some variation on the profile described here should be expected.

Name: Colombian – 365 Everyday Value
Review: ong>For those looking for a decent cup at a great price.

Name: Guatemalan Plantation Direct
Review: ong>Those seeking a balanced cup of (Industrial) Joe.

Name: India Karnataka Thorarihunkal Maya Estate
Review: ong>Those more laid back than get up and go.

Name: Superstition Sunrise Brazil
Review: ong>Those who avoid acidy intensity and enjoy subtle natural variations on a theme of chocolate.

Name: Bali
Review: ong>Definitely a romantic's coffee, a surprising and (for a classicist perhaps shocking) variation on an Indonesian theme: sweet, pungently nutty and earthy.

Name: Ethiopia Yirgacheffe
Review: ong>For those who prefer the smooth and naturally sweet to the vibrant and wild.

Name: 100% Colombian Whole Bean
Review: ong>As we tasted it, a traditional breakfast cup that both lives up to and transcends its venerable brand. Given the volume and anonymity of coffee needed to fill the Eight O'Clock 100% Colombian bags over the course of a year, some variation on the profile described here should be expected.

Name: Fazenda Sao Joao Brasil
Review: ong>Accessible, suave, yet complex breakfast cup. Aficionados may want to sample this coffee as a demonstration of how pure a "natural," dried-in-the-fruit coffee can be when the farmer is obsessive and the climate during harvest is perfect.
Coffee Origin: Coromandel growing region, Minas Gerais State, Brazil

Name: Fazenda do Serrado Brasil
Review: ong>Aficionados may find an intriguing hint of Kenya in this bourbon-derived Brazil, rounded and enriched by dried-in-the-fruit processing. Others may simply enjoy a richly balanced, crisply fruit-toned cup.
Coffee Origin: Carmo de Minas growing region, Minas Gerais State, Brazil

Name: Brasil Cerrado Fazenda Esperanca Lot 302 Pulped Natural
Review: ong>A quiet, sneakily pleasing morning coffee.
Coffee Origin: Cerrado growing region, Minas Gerais State, Brazil.

Name: Brazil Fazenda Boa Vista
Review: ong>A splendid example of a new style of specialty Brazil, much quieter than Kenya but just as sweetly tart and complex.
Coffee Origin: Carmo de Minas growing region, Minas Gerais State, Brazil

Name: Kenya AA Estate Gituto
Review: ong>Springtime in a cup for late winter mornings.

Name: Ethiopia Yirgacheffe
Review: ong>A classically lyric Yirgacheffe with a particularly fresh, meadowy lilt to the flowers. As breakfast cup, both distinctive and accessible.
Coffee Origin: Yirgacheffe growing region, Sidamo Province, southern Ethiopia.

Name: Organic Fair-Trade Mocha Java
Review: ong>A brandy and cigars coffee for the socially and environmentally correct.

Name: Ethiopia Yirgacheffe Fair-Trade Organic
Review: ong>Solid social and environmental credentials for a quiet, relatively deep-toned rendition of the floral and citrus Yirgacheffe profile.

Name: Ascension
Review: ong>A striking coffee with exotic aromatics, roasty and complex but impressively smooth.

Name: Costa Rica El Conquistador
Review: ong>A Costa Rica for non-conformists: classic acidity, big body but a hint of ambiguous, perhaps exotic pungency in the aromatics.

Name: Rwanda Blue Bourbon Black Apron Exclusive
Review: ong>Starbucks watchers or convenience shoppers. An obviously interesting green coffee that perhaps lost energy from origin to cup. Put away the Charbucks cliches, however, because I would not call it over-roasted, just dulled either by fading or perhaps by very slow roast profiling.

Name: Brazil Opus 1 Exotic
Review: ong>For those who enjoy coffee but find themselves sensitive to some of its properties, this is a genuinely natural low-caffeine and low-acid alternative.
Coffee Origin: Cerrado growing region, Minas Gerais State, Brazil.

Name: Yemen Mocca Sanani
Review: ong>A good example of a famous and historical origin.
Coffee Origin: North-central Yemen, wet of the capital city of Sana'a

Name: JR Reserve Blend
Review: ong>A felicitous marriage of what seem particularly strong-charactered green coffees and the Peet's deep, slow dark roast make this a good introduction to the Peet's style for curious non-Peetniks.

Name: Colombia Micro-Lot Wilmer Delgado
Review: ong>The nose knows on this one.

Name: Bolivia Cup of Excellence 2007
Review: ong>A subtle, refreshing daytime coffee.

Name: El Dorado
Review: ong>Not an extremely light-roasted coffee, but it reads that way: bright, pure, austerely refreshing.

Name: Guatemala Finca Hermosa Microlot Vista Hermosa
Review: ong>A big, brightly sweet breakfast cup.

Name: Ethiopia Yirgacheffe Aricha Selection #7
Review: ong>Voluptuaries and brandy swirlers.
Coffee Origin: Yirgacheffe growing region, Sidamo Province, southern Ethiopia.

Name: Panama Elida Estate
Review: ong>A grand but ingratiating, complete coffee gesture. Very light-roasted, but the green coffee is so sweet and roundly balanced that those who enjoy medium-dark roasts should take pleasure in it.
